abstract: Documents in a settlement between the Bank of America and the Justice Department read like a highlight reel of mortgage sins.
snippet: Documents in a settlement between the Bank of America and the Justice Department read like a highlight reel of mortgage sins.
lead_paragraph: A founder of Countrywide Financial warned three years before the housing market collapsed that his company could face “financial and reputational catastrophe” if it continued holding certain risky mortgages on its balance sheet. Still, Countrywide continued to sell these loans to investors.

headline.main: Bank of America Papers Show Conflict and Trickery in Mortgages
headline.print_headline: Bank Papers Show Conflict and Trickery in Mortgages

byline.original: By Michael Corkery and Ben Protess

abstract: Bank of America’s $16.65 billion settlement may cost the bank significantly less. | Wall Street banks are digging deeper to keep top talent. | Family Dollar rejected Dollar General’s takeover bid. | A judge in New York scolded Argentina for its attempt to skirt a U.S. court ruling on bond payments.
snippet: Bank of America’s $16.65 billion settlement may cost the bank significantly less. | Wall Street banks are digging deeper to keep top talent. | Family Dollar rejected Dollar General’s takeover bid. | A judge in New York scolded Argentina for its at...
lead_paragraph: THE TRUE COST OF BANK OF AMERICA’S DEAL | The Justice Department has collected huge sums from big banks for their role in selling troubled mortgages before the financial crisis. But in the end, the financial pain inflicted by these settlements ‒ including the $16.65 billion deal with Bank of America announced on Thursday ‒ may not be as great as these numbers suggest, DealBook’s Peter Eavis and Michael Corkery write. The actual financial burden for Bank of America, for example, may not exceed $12 billion, significantly less than the number the government trumpets.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: The True Cost of Bank of America’s Settlement

abstract: The Bank of America settlement may close a chapter of the financial crisis, but the Justice Department can still pursue civil cases against former Countrywide executives, writes Peter J. Henning in the White Collar Watch column.
snippet: The Bank of America settlement may close a chapter of the financial crisis, but the Justice Department can still pursue civil cases against former Countrywide executives, writes Peter J. Henning in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The latest settlement with a big bank, this time Bank of America’s $16.65 billion resolution over shoddy mortgage and related mortgage-backed securities that lost much of their value, has all the accoutrements we have come to expect: a claim of historic significance supported by a statement of facts referencing a few embarrassing e-mails to establish the requisite venality for a large penalty. A prominent feature is a news conference where Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. hails the resolution as yet another blow against the reckless (or worse) banking practices that led to the financial crisis.

headline.main: Blurred Lines in Big Bank Mortgage Settlements
